rnalysis.filtering.CountFilter¶

class rnalysis.filtering.CountFilter(fname: Union[str, pathlib.Path], drop_columns: Union[str, List[str]] = False)¶

A class that receives a count matrix and can filter it according to various characteristics.

Attributes

df: pandas DataFrame

A DataFrame that contains the count matrix contents. The DataFrame is modified upon usage of filter operations.

shape: tuple (rows, columns)

The dimensions of df.

columns: list

The columns of df.

fname: pathlib.Path

The path and filename for the purpose of saving df as a csv file. Updates automatically when filter operations are applied.

index_set: set

All of the indices in the current DataFrame (which were not removed by previously used filter methods) as a set.

index_string: string

A string of all feature indices in the current DataFrame separated by newline.

triplicates: list

Returns a nested list of the column names in the CountFilter, grouped by alphabetical order into triplicates. For example, if counts.columns is [‘A_rep1’,’A_rep2’,’A_rep3’,’B_rep1’,’B_rep2’,_B_rep3’], then counts.triplicates will be [[‘A_rep1’,’A_rep2’,’A_rep3’],[‘B_rep1’,’B_rep2’,_B_rep3’]]

__init__(fname: Union[str, pathlib.Path], drop_columns: Union[str, List[str]] = False)¶
Parameters

  • fname (Union[str, Path]) – full path/filename of the .csv file to be loaded into the Filter object

  • drop_columns (str, list of str, or False (default False)) – if a string or list of strings are specified, the columns of the same name/s will be dropped from the loaded DataFrame.

Examples
>>> from rnalysis import filtering
>>> d = filtering.Filter("tests/counted.csv")

Methods

__init__(fname[, drop_columns])

param fname

full path/filename of the .csv file to be loaded into the Filter object

biotypes([format, ref])

Returns a DataFrame of the biotypes in the Filter object and their count.

clustergram([sample_names, metric, linkage])

Performs hierarchical clustering and plots a clustergram on the base-2 log of a given set of samples.

describe([percentiles])

Generate descriptive statistics that summarize the central tendency, dispersion and shape of the dataset’s distribution, excluding NaN values.

difference(*others[, return_type, inplace])

Keep only the features that exist in the first Filter object/set but NOT in the others.

filter_biotype([biotype, ref, opposite, inplace])

Filters out all features that do not match the indicated biotype/biotypes.

filter_by_attribute([attributes, mode, ref, …])

Filters features according to user-defined attributes from an Attribute Reference Table.

filter_by_row_sum([threshold, opposite, inplace])

remove all features which have less then ‘threshold’ reads per million in all conditions.

filter_low_reads([threshold, opposite, inplace])

remove all features which have less then ‘threshold’ reads per million in all conditions.

filter_percentile(percentile, column[, …])

Removes all entries above the specified percentile in the specified column.

filter_top_n(by[, n, ascending, …])

Sort the rows by the values of specified column or columns, then keep only the top ‘n’ rows.

fold_change(numerator, denominator[, …])

Calculate the fold change between the numerator condition and the denominator condition, and return it as a FoldChangeFilter object.

from_folder(folder_path[, norm_to_rpm, …])

Iterates over HTSeq count .txt files in a given folder and combines them into a single CountFilter table.

head([n])

Return the first n rows of the Filter object.

intersection(*others[, return_type, inplace])

Keep only the features that exist in ALL of the given Filter objects/sets.

normalize_to_rpm(special_counter_fname[, …])

Normalizes the reads in the CountFilter to reads per million (RPM).

normalize_with_scaling_factors(…[, inplace])

Normalizes the reads in the CountFilter using pre-calculated scaling factors.

number_filters(column, operator, value[, …])

Applay a number filter (greater than, equal, lesser than) on a particular column in the Filter object.

pairplot([sample_list, log2])

Plot pairwise relationships in the dataset.

pca([sample_names, n_components, …])

runs and plots a PCA for a given set of samples.

plot_expression(features, sample_grouping[, …])

Plot the average expression and standard error of the specified features under the specified conditions.

print_features()

Print the feature indices in the Filter object, separated by newline.

save_csv([alt_filename])

Saves the current filtered data to a .csv file.

scatter_sample_vs_sample(sample1, sample2[, …])

Generate a scatter plot where every dot is a feature, the x value is log10 of reads (counts, RPM, RPKM, TPM, etc) in sample1, the y value is log10 of reads in sample2.

split_by_percentile(percentile, column)

Splits the Filter object into two Filter objects: below and above the specified percentile in the spcfieid column.

split_by_reads([threshold])

Splits the features in the current CountFilter object into two complementary, non-overlapping CountFilter objects, based on the their maximum expression level.

split_by_attribute(attributes[, ref])

Splits the Filter object into multiple Filter objects, each corresponding to one of the specified Attribute Reference Table attributes.

symmetric_difference(other[, return_type])

Returns a set/string of the WBGene indices that exist either in the first Filter object/set OR the second, but NOT in both (set symmetric difference).

tail([n])

Return the last n rows of the Filter object.

text_filters(column, operator, value[, …])

Applay a text filter (equals, contains, starts with, ends with) on a particular column in the Filter object.

union(*others[, return_type])

Returns a set/string of the union of WBGene indices between multiple Filter objects (the indices that exist in at least one of the Filter objects/sets).

violin_plot([samples])

Generates a violin plot of the specified samples in the CountFilter object.
